items.title: Wiki Outdated Functions
items.body:
When testing the code here, I found that the function names (and parameters) are outdated. Not sure if this is an issue in other parts of the wiki. The correct function names have underscores and are not in camelCase.

https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/wiki/5.-Segmentation#silence-removal-and-event-detection
from pyAudioAnalysis import audioBasicIO as aIO
from pyAudioAnalysis import audioSegmentation as aS
[Fs, x] = aIO.**readAudioFile**("data/recording1.wav")
segments = aS.silence_removal(x, Fs, 0.020, 0.020, **smoothWindow** = 1.0, **Weight** = 0.3, plot = True)

correct functions:
[Fs, x] = aIO.**read_audio_file**("data/recording1.wav")
segments = aS.silence_removal(x, Fs, 0.020, 0.020, **smooth_window** = 1.0, **weight** = 0.3, plot = True)

items.title: ShortTermFeatures.feature_extraction returns 68 features not 34
items.body:
According to the wiki https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/wiki/3.-Feature-Extraction, "eature_extraction() returns a numpy matrix of 34 rows and N columns, where N is the number of short-term frames that fit into the input audio recording."

However, I am getting 68 features, even tho my audio is mono:

```
from pyAudioAnalysis import audioBasicIO
from pyAudioAnalysis import ShortTermFeatures

def pAA(filename):
    [Fs, x] = audioBasicIO.read_audio_file(filename)
    x = audioBasicIO.stereo_to_mono(x)
    # The following code uses feature_extraction() of the ShortTermFeatures.py file to extract the short term
    # feature sequences for an audio signal, using a frame size of 50 msecs and a frame step of 25 msecs
    # (50% overlap).
    F, f_names = ShortTermFeatures.feature_extraction(x, Fs, 0.050*Fs, 0.025*Fs)
    return F

pAA("VARIATION-004-024.mp3").shape
```
(68, 99)

Why? The last 34 features are delta features, perhaps these should be documented?

When would you need them?

items.title: IndexError: index -1 is out of bounds for axis 0 with size 0
items.body:
I am attempting to run the following command in order to train the HMM on audio segments. I tried the sample code 
          **python audioAnalysis.py trainHMMsegmenter_fromfile -i data/count.wav --ground data/count.segments -o hmmcount -mw 0.1 -ms 0.1**

and the model trained successfully. 


But when I try my own data:

**python audioAnalysis.py trainHMMsegmenter_fromfile -i data/Segmentation/10.wav --ground data/Segmentation/10.segments -o hmmcount -mw 1.0 -ms 1.0**


I get the following error:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "audioAnalysis.py", line 578, in <module>
    args.mtwin, args.mtstep)
  File "audioAnalysis.py", line 185, in trainHMMsegmenter_fromfile
    aS.train_hmm_from_file(wavFile, gtFile, hmmModelName, mt_win, mt_step)
  File "C:\Users\RichardHu\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pyAudioAnalysis\audioSegmentation.py", line 365, in train_hmm_from_file
    flags, class_names = segments_to_labels(seg_start, seg_end, seg_labs, mid_step)
  File "C:\Users\RichardHu\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pyAudioAnalysis\audioSegmentation.py", line 115, in segments_to_labels
    while index < end_times[-1]:
IndexError: index -1 is out of bounds for axis 0 with size 0

When I **print (seg_start, seg_end, seg_labs)** for the wav files, I get empy lists of [] [] []

Has anyone had a similar issue? Is there perhaps a specific issue with my .WAV (or .SEGMENTS file) that is causing this?

Note: I ensured that the wav file is mono and not stereo by converting it using ffmpeg. The full audio format is: Audio: pcm_s16le ([1][0][0][0] / 0x0001), 16000 Hz, mono, s16, 256 kb/s

items.title: audioTrainTest.py updates required
items.body:
In the code of pyAudioAnalysis. The code for audioTrainTest.py, contains a function 
`def train_random_forest`
The description in the comments then talks about SVM training rather than Random Forest.

Similarly, Gradient Boosting and Decision Trees also needs to be updated.

items.title: ERROR: invalid delimiter in diarizationExample.segments
items.body:
The delimiter was changed to 'tab' in the commit: https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/commit/391e269a923e2d3abaccde2b7e6a3afc9793cc09
https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/blob/391e269a923e2d3abaccde2b7e6a3afc9793cc09/pyAudioAnalysis/data/diarizationExample.segments#L1

But parser doesn't support it; https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/blob/5b333d9bd8e3c8e36e7339a94c2d51bf22d09b38/pyAudioAnalysis/audioSegmentation.py#L161

items.title: Out of date wiki
items.body:
On the [segmentation wiki page](https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/wiki/5.-Segmentation), there are code examples which seem to be from an earlier version (pre-refactoring).

To bring these up to date, references to the following functions should be updated
1. `mtFileClassification()` -> `mid_term_file_classification()`
2. `mtFeatureExtraction()` -> `mid_feature_extraction()`
3. `trainHMM_fromFile ` -> `train_hmm_from_file()`
4. `trainHMM_fromDir` -> `train_hmm_from_dir()`
5. `hmmSegmentation()` -> `hmm_segmentation()`
6. `evaluateSegmentationClassificationDir()` -> `evaluate_segmentation_classification_dir()`
7. `aS.silenceRemoval(x, Fs, 0.020, 0.020, smoothWindow = 1.0, Weight = 0.3, plot = True)` -> `segments = aS.silence_removal(x, Fs, 0.020, 0.020, smooth_window = 1.0, weight = 0.3, plot = True)

I may have missed a couple. I would have PRed but it seems like I can't for wiki pages. Great library!

items.title: Matplotlib error

from pyAudioAnalysis import ShortTermFeatures
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
[Fs, x] = audioBasicIO.read_audio_file("pyAudioAnalysis/data/scottish.wav")

F, f_names = ShortTermFeatures.feature_extraction(x, Fs, 0.050*Fs, 0.025*Fs)
plt.subplot(2,1,1); plt.plot(F[0,:]); plt.xlabel('Frame no'); plt.ylabel(f_names[0]) 
plt.subplot(2,1,2); plt.plot(F[1,:]); plt.xlabel('Frame no'); plt.ylabel(f_names[1]); plt.show()

items.title: Speaker Diarization: Segmentation and Clustering
items.body:
Hi,

I am working on a speaker diarization project. I need to segment an audio file based on speaker change detection and then cluster the segments from same speakers. Is it possible to do so using pyAudioAnalysis without using its own speakerDiarization method? Both steps to be done separately.

PS: built-in segmentation methods segment n audio with supervised class name. I just want to segment speaker segments with any class name.

items.title: Perform file regression on descriptor file instead of audio file
items.body:
Is there a way to train a regression model, then perform single file regression on a descriptor file of an audio file instead of the actual audio file itself? 

My problem is that users will submit their audio files to me for analysis. I analyse them and send back the results. Then I delete the audio file because it's not mine and I can't store it. But if I can export some sort of descriptor file for that audio file, then later I'd like to be able to train a new model and compute the results for that descriptor file using regression. 

Is something like this possible with this library?

items.title: Wiki page says "Gradiet" instead of "Gradient"
items.body: On https://github.com/tyiannak/pyAudioAnalysis/wiki/4.-Classification-and-Regression

items.title: Memory leak in stFeatureExtraction
items.body:
I tried to build a audio processing server, but I found a memory leak issue when I use [audioFeatureExtraction.stFeatureExtraction]. Then I wrote a test script as following(run with Python 2.7):

from pyAudioAnalysis import audioBasicIO
from pyAudioAnalysis import audioFeatureExtraction
audio_file = "sample_origin.wav"
[fs, data] = audioBasicIO.readAudioFile(audio_file)
while True:
    features = audioFeatureExtraction.stFeatureExtraction(data, fs, 960, 960)

With the Windows task manager, I found the memory it used keep increasing, from 200MB to 270MB within 20 minutes. I tested my script both on Windows 10  and Ubuntu 16.04, and it seemed the same result.

Anyone has come across this problem? I wish to make sure it's a bug or not.
Looking forward to responses.

items.title: Remove reload(sys) from audioFeatureExtraction.py
items.body:
In short my question is if it is safe to remove the following lines from audioFeatureExtraction.py  
`reload(sys)`
`sys.setdefaultencoding('utf8')`

Maybe I have looked in the wrong place, but I found no tests which could be run, to check the change. 

I'm using Jupyter notebooks for my programming. When I used audioFeatureExtraction (more specifically the function stFeatureExtraction) I noticed some strange behaviour of the output of the cells. For those that don know, notebooks use cells, which have independent output. The strange behaviour is that the output is first printed at the wrong cells and is not updating after a second run. Restarting the kernel repeats this behaviour. Removing the lines above returned the output behaviour to normal.

Here is a more concrete example. When an unit test is run, it is expected to list the results in the output of the cell the test is in. All my other tests, which don't use audioFeatureExtraction do this. With audioFeatureExtraction however the results are printed at the cell with class which is tested. A second run of the test cell can print the results under the previous results at the target class cell (it should be replaced if it were the right cell). It can also not output anything at all, which defeats the purpose of the test.

items.title: trainSVM_feature ERROR: No data found in any input folder!
items.body:
Hi all,
I'm trying to this tutorial: [link](http://rwx.io/blog/2016/04/08/bp-pyaudioanalysis/)
When I run this python code(createClassifierModel.py):
```
#!/usr/local/bin/python2
from pyAudioAnalysis import audioTrainTest as aT
import os
from sys import argv
script, dirname = argv

subdirectories = os.listdir(dirname)[:4]
subdirectories.pop(0)

subdirectories = [dirname + "/" + subDirName for subDirName in subdirectories]
#subdirectories = [dirname + subDirName for subDirName in subdirectories]

print(subdirectories)
aT.featureAndTrain(subdirectories, 1.0, 1.0, aT.shortTermWindow, aT.shortTermStep, "svm", "svmModel", False)
```
then, the result is:
```
$ python createClassifierModel.py trainingData/
['trainingData/breaking_glass', 'trainingData/vacuum']
Analyzing file 1 of 1: trainingData/breaking_glass/breaking_glass_02.wav
Analyzing file 1 of 1: trainingData/vacuum/apli-vacuummini.wav
trainSVM_feature ERROR: No data found in any input folder!
```

How Can I fix this error?
My folder tree is :
├── audioClassification
│   ├── pyAudioAnalysis
│   │   └── data
│   │       ├── beat
│   │       └── speechEmotion
│   ├── sampleData
│   └── trainingData
│       ├── breaking_glass/breaking_glass_02.wav
│       ├── bubbles/Bubbles.wav
│       └── vacuum/apli-vacuummini.wav

And my PC: Linux mint 18.3 Cinnamon 64-bit(Ubuntu 16.04)
the python version is: Python 2.7.12 (default, Dec  4 2017, 14:50:18)


Please help me.

Thanks.

I had to check out if the .wav files are sampled 44100/16bit and their respective 4 files (2x .csv+2x.npy)  after feature extraction are present in each of the mentioned 4 class folders. And they are there.

The error sticks even after separating the .csv from the .npy ones, each in its separate subfolders and instructing python to only read the .npy subfolders for each class when training with knn method. 

Any clue? Thank you for your time.

items.title: empty array or plot axis dimension mismatch in silenceRemovel()
items.body:
Just remind in my test case, the following two lines will result in T1 or T2 nan if L1 is 0 or 1:
T1 = numpy.mean(E[0:L1]) + 0.000000000000001                 
T2 = numpy.mean(E[-L1:-1]) + 0.000000000000001 
we can solve this according to the value of L1.

The plot will fail due to mismatch dimension in the following line of code:
plt.plot(numpy.arange(0, ProbOnset.shape[0] * stStep, stStep), ProbOnset)
I solved this by the following:
plt.plot(numpy.arange(0, ProbOnset.shape[0] * stStep - stStep/2, stStep), ProbOnset)

Thank you all the contributors for this wonderful tool.
Regards

items.title: bug in PLOT of stChromagram()
items.body:
Hi,
you should add the following line after the Ratio calculation : 
Ratio = chromaGramToPlot.shape[1] / (3*chromaGramToPlot.shape[0])
if Ratio < 1 : Ratio=1

I had Ratio equal to 0 that created problems with range afterwards.
best regards

items.title: eyeD3 version
items.body:
this project is amazing! I have tried the speaker diarization feature and it really works! Super Cool! However it is also worthwhile to specify the version of eyeD3 being used.. While I was installing this package,  there was an error on eyeD3 module being used. The package will not work with the latest eyeD3 of versions 0.7.x but with versions 0.6.x. 

Hope this project will be added in PyPi. The project is promising!

items.title: using the available trained HMM model for speech-music discrimination
items.body:
playing around with your interesting project, I encountered an issue whilst trying to perform a HMM-based segmentation and classification, using the available trained HMM model for speech-music discrimination.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2489127/7660616/fb2bbf1e-fb4b-11e4-9ae7-ce5488398c36.png)

note that I am running this on an EC2 server with only ssh access.
